New rules apply in order to access Andorra from outside the EU or similar (e.g. United Kingdom), that you must have proof of either a vaccination certificate - a complete series received more than 14 days ago - recovery from the disease - has passed the COVID in the last 6 months - or a PCR / TMA test with a negative result performed in the last 72 hours before entering the Principality. The document must be carried to show it to the public authorities if they so request. In the event that the authorities detect the entry of people from outside the EU or similar and who do not have the aforementioned documentation, they must carry out a mandatory preventive confinement of 14 days, which may be reduced to 10 if they are made a diagnostic test to detect COVID-19. https://archive.vn/ua9Hj

Special regulations for Styria  Measures for the entire federal state of Styria    From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:  â¢ In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  â¢ Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  â¢ External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  â¢ A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    Source: https://archive.vn/aPY6X#selection-935.0-1043.95 [Special regulations for Styria]

"From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location. Further information can be found on the website of the  Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research (BMBWF)."    *Universities*  Does the â3-G ruleâ - tested, recovered, vaccinated - also apply to universities and colleges?Inhalt zuklappen  In any case, it is recommended that the so-called "3-G rule" also authorize access to universities and colleges. As in other areas of life, those who have been tested, recovered and vaccinated should be granted access to the campus. For this, the current legal basis, the 2nd COVID-19 University Act , has been extended to the upcoming winter semester 2021/22 until February 28, 2022 and adjusted accordingly. The 3G rule is particularly relevant for participation in face-to-face courses, face-to-face exams or participation in selection, aptitude and admission procedures on site . The proven approach remains that the University and college managements are responsible for determining the specific corona measures at their locations. They know the respective conditions and requirements on site best. However, they have to guarantee the applicable level of protection, for which the current, general corona protection and hygiene measures offer a valuable basis.     Therefore, please inform yourself directly at your respective university or college how they organize their teaching and examination operations and which Corona measures they intend to take.    The 3-G rule states:     The 2nd COVID-19 Opening Ordinance defines precise criteria as to when one belongs to the group of people who have a "low epidemiological risk".   - Anyone who has been vaccinated with a centrally approved COVID-19 vaccine is considered vaccinated. The first vaccination counts from the 22nd day after the 1st prick for a maximum of three months from the time of vaccination. After the 2nd bite you are immunized for a total of 20 days. Vaccines for which only one vaccination is intended (e.g. from Johnson & Johnson) are valid from the 22nd day after the vaccination for a total of 270 days. This also applies to people who can be proven to have recovered as soon as they have received the first stitch.   - As tested applies to those who can provide evidence of a negative PCR test or a negative antigen test. PCR tests are valid for 72 hours from the time the sample is taken, and antigen tests for 48 hours if performed by an authorized body. Self-tests that are recorded in an official data processing system in the federal states are valid for 24 hours. In addition, there are exceptionally supervised point-of-sale tests for one-time entry of sports facilities, business premises, restaurants, hotels or an event.  - As recovered applies to those who can present a separation notice of a SARS-COV-2 infection or a medical confirmation within the last six months. Alternatively, a corresponding antibody test can be presented, which, however, must not be older than three months.  You can find more detailed information about the 3-G rule and the other applicable protective and hygiene measures on the website of the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection (BMSGPK) .     Sources:   https://archive.vn/MVQ1H [Nationwide measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004164552/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/HS-Uni/Aktuelles/corona/corona_faq.html  https://archive.vn/drFIv [Special regulations for Carinthia]

On October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission classifies all of Austria as high risk. The federal states of Carinthia, Lower Austria, Upper Austria and Styria are also rated as having a high risk. Burgenland as well as Tyrol, Vorarlberg and Vienna are rated with medium risk. Salzburg is classified as very high risk.    The classification for the education sector is still risk level I for Vorarlberg and risk level II for all other federal states.     Source: https://archive.vn/C5hBO#selection-543.0-563.129 [Corona traffic light map]

"From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location."    *Vorarlberg*  In its meeting on October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission determined that the schools in Vorarlberg will remain in risk level 1 .    Test and mask requirement:  Schoolchildren: There is no MNS requirement in the entire school building and there is no longer any compulsory test. However, antigen tests can still be carried out voluntarily. These are confirmed by the school in the sticker pass.  Teaching and administrative staff: There is no MNS obligation in the entire school building. For staff who have not been vaccinated / have not recovered, an external PCR test must still be submitted once a week; further antigen tests must be carried out at the school. Vaccinated and convalescents can voluntarily test themselves with antigen tests.  External persons must present a 3-G certificate and wear MNS during their entire stay at the school.     Arrangement of compulsory tests and masks:  If suspected cases arise during the voluntary antigen tests or during tests outside the school, all schools have the option of ordering a temporary test or mask compulsory for individual classes or the entire school for a maximum of one week . Such an arrangement requires the approval of the Education Directorate.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    *Carinthia*  Additional measures in music schools apply to Carinthia.    Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From September 13, 2021 (until February 13, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    The 3-G rule applies when entering child education and care facilities, as well as day-care centers and when staying in closed rooms in these facilities. If this is not provided, an MNS must be worn.  The provider of a facility must implement the requirements of the COVID-19 guidelines for child education and care facilities.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  The 3-G certificate is a prerequisite for caring for children in after-school care centers. If this cannot be achieved, the child has to wear an MNS.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/i1aIC - Vorarlberg  https://archive.vn/tfL5J - Carinthia  https://archive.vn/vhzaV#selection-809.0-809.28 - Risk levels in Upper Austria  https://archive.vn/77eIK - COVID-19 agricultural school ordinance 2021/22 applies to Salzburg   https://archive.vn/Jmj3m - Styria  https://archive.vn/cN2uW - Vienna  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/v9L39 - Good starting conditions for the winter semester 2021/22 - 80 percent of the students vaccinated  https://archive.vn/fmtyw - Coronavirus - Current Measures

At work  â¢ Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts, if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.  â¢ The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.  â¢ The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  â¢ By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Customer areas  â¢ An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.   â¢ When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.  â¢ The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    3-G rule  The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:  â¢ Gastronomy  â¢ Body-hugging services  â¢ Hotel and lodging  â¢ Leisure facilities (e.g. dance schools, zoos)  â¢ Cultural establishments   â¢ Non-public sports facilities  â¢ Meetings (from a number of participants of more than 100 people)  â¢ Trade and consumer fairs, congresses  â¢ Coaches and excursion boats    *Leisure, sport and culture*    Leisure  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:   â¢ Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks  â¢ Baths and facilities   â¢ Dance schools  â¢ Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos  â¢ Show mines  â¢ Facilities for the practice of prostitution  â¢ IndoorspielplÃ¤tze  â¢ Paintballanlagen  â¢ Museum railways  â¢ Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens    The following applies in this area:  â¢ Customers must show a 3-G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.  â¢ Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Culture  â¢ Unvaccinated persons must wear an FFP2 mask in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives.  â¢ For cultural institutions in which mainly meetings take place, such as in particular theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.    Sport  â¢ The 3-G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   â¢ All sports are permitted, and contact sports are again possible.  â¢ Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  â¢ There are detailed regulations for the exercise of sports by top athletes.    *Gastronomy and accommodation*    Gastronomy  When visiting a restaurant, the following rules must be observed:  â¢ 3-G rule (see above)    The operators of catering establishments must also ensure the following:  â¢ Self-service buffets can be operated subject to hygiene requirements.  â¢ Every catering business must create a prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  â¢ Mandatory collection of customer data.  â¢ The 3-G rule does not apply to the pick-up of food and drinks, as well as snack bars and catering stands.     Night gastronomy  â¢ Access to the night catering is possible for vaccinated and convalescent people, as well as people with a current negative PCR test result (max. 72 hours old). The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay. The new restrictions on night dining do not apply to gatherings such as tent parties.     Accommodation  â¢ The accommodation establishments are allowed to reopen under Covid conditions. To do this, the operators must create a COVID-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  â¢ The 3-G rule applies when entering for the first time. If the validity expires during the stay, a new proof must be provided.  â¢ For the use of the culinary offer in hotels and accommodation establishments, the regulations of the catering trade apply. The 3-G rule must be observed for the use of gastronomy, wellness and fitness offers.  â¢ Mandatory collection of customer data.    Source: https://archive.vn/MVQ1H  [Nationwide measures]

Customer areas  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.   When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    At work  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Leisure, sport and culture    leisure  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:     Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks  Baths and facilities   Dance schools  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos  Show mines  Facilities for the practice of prostitution  Indoor playgrounds  Paintball systems  Museum railways  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens  The following applies in this area:    Customers must show a 3-G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Culture  Unvaccinated persons must wear an FFP2 mask in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.  Sports  The 3-G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   All sports are permitted, and contact sports are again possible.  Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  There are detailed regulations for the exercise of sports by top athletes.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

In general:  â¢ In principle, there are no longer any maximum limits and capacity restrictions.  â¢ There is no longer a mask requirement at events.  â¢ Meetings with more than 25 participants are only permitted on the condition that the person responsible for the meeting only allows the participants to enter if they can provide proof of 3G.  â¢ Meetings of 100 people or more are notifiable. The participants have to show a 3G certificate, which has to be checked by the person responsible. He must also develop and implement a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.  â¢ Meetings of 500 people or more must be approved. The 3-G rule also applies here. A prevention concept and the appointment of a COVID-19 officer is required.    Source: https://archive.vn/MVQ1H  [Nationwide measures]

Public transport  An FFP2 mask must be worn in closed rooms when using taxis and taxi-like companies, cable cars and rack and pinion railways for mass transportation and in the associated stations, platforms, stops, train stations and airports as well as their respective connecting structures.  The operator of cable cars and cog railways has to appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  The following applies to the use of coaches and excursion boats in occasional traffic:  The operator may only let people in if they can present a 3-G certificate. The person must keep this proof available for the duration of the stay.  The operator must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    Source: https://archive.vn/dAqZ5#selection-1775.0-1831.101 [Nationwide measures]

The 5th amendment to the COVID-19 Entry Ordinance 2021 brings with it some changes:  â¢ So far, a second vaccination was valid for nine months. In the future, second vaccinations as well as each subsequent vaccination will be recognized upon entry even if they were up to 360 days ago. As evidence of a low epidemiological risk, the 3rd vaccination (or the 2nd vaccination for single vaccines and those who have recovered with a vaccination bite) is now included. There must be at least 14 days between the 1st and 2nd vaccination and at least 120 days between the 2nd and 3rd vaccination.    â¢ Those who have recovered are treated on an equal footing with those who have been fully immunized.    â¢ There is a tightening of the entry regulations from several countries: This affects the USA, the Western Balkans states Serbia, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Kosovo and Albania. In addition, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brunei, Israel, Japan and Thailand will be removed from Appendix 1. For these countries, the entry regulations of the other states and areas apply again .    â¢ There are also changes to the list of virus variant states: Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe and Uruguay will be deleted from this list. Chile, Costa Rica and Suriname are new to this list. For countries that are on the list of virus variant states, extensive entry restrictions and mandatory quarantine still apply.    â¢ Spain is no longer subject to any special provisions for entry by air according to Â§ 5a. For entries from Spain, the regulations in Appendix 1 apply.    â¢ The validity of the regulation will be extended from September 20 to October 31, 2021.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004173733/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

A corresponding financing decision is planned for Tuesday in the health committee. The free self-tests from pharmacies, on the other hand, expire at the end of the month."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004191853/https://www.wienerzeitung.at/themen/sars-cov-2/2123632-Gratis-Tests-bleiben-bis-Ende-Maerz.html [Wiener Zeitung article]

Clearance and mouth and nose protection  â¢ There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.    â¢ In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous     MNS wearing obligation.  â¢ In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions is becoming an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.    â¢ Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    Source:  https://archive.vn/MVQ1H#selection-1661.0-1713.47 [Nationwide measures]

Clearance and mouth and nose protection  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.  In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous MNS wearing obligation.  In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions becomes an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.  Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    2nd amendment to the 2nd COVID-19 - Measures Ordinance  Wearing an FFP 2 mask is compulsory in food retailing, including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with associated sales outlets for food, pharmacies, banks, post offices and public transport.  â¢For those who have not been vaccinated or who have not recovered It is compulsory for people to wear an FFP 2 mask in the entire trade, the day-care facilities in care for the elderly and in the disabled area, as well as cultural facilities (museums, libraries, theaters, cinemas, etc.).    Mask requirement in Vienna    In Vienna, the mask requirement applies in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/dAqZ5#selection-1711.0-1711.39 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX#selection-1537.0-1601.180 [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/XEvAR [Vienna]

Measures for the entire state of Salzburg  From October 18, 2021, additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19:  â¢ In addition to the FFP2 mask requirement in public pharmacies, food retailers, banks, and post offices, there is still an FFP2 mask requirement without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard  for all customers in the  customer areas of business premises in closed rooms and in connecting structures that are structurally connected Business premises (e.g. shopping centers, market halls).  â¢ The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to body-hugging services and to all cultural institutions.  â¢ Employees in retail, body-friendly services and cultural institutions are exempt from this.    Source: https://archive.vn/tYjaF [Measures for the entire state of Salzburg]

Clearance and mouth and nose protection - Nationwide Measures  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.    In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous MNS wearing obligation.    In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions becomes an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.    Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

For the federal state of Vienna, the following additional, stricter measures apply from October 1 to October 31 inclusive.    Bedside hospitals and health resorts  â¢ Visits are limited to one person per day and patient.  â¢ Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to provide bedside hospitals as well as old people's and nursing homes with proof of a negative PCR test (in exceptional cases an antigen test can be carried out when starting work and a PCR test has to be carried out), with proof of a vaccination, international vaccination pass, segregation notice and proof enter via neutralizing antibodies. Once a week, all employees, owners and operators have to submit proof of a negative PCR test. An FFP2 mask or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard must also be worn in closed rooms.    General regulations  Retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled    The following applies to visitors:  â¢ The operator may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can provide evidence of a low epidemiological risk (3-G rule). The visitor or the accompanying person must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.  â¢ The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they wear an FFP2 mask throughout the visit or stay, provided that there is no other suitable protective device for spatial separation between residents and visitors or accompanying persons same level of protection guaranteed.  â¢ Visitors who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.    The following applies to employees:   â¢ Employees need proof of a low epidemiological risk. If a test certificate is presented, it must be renewed every seven days. If the 3-G proof provided has exceeded its validity, an FFP2 mask must be worn.  â¢ Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.    The following applies to operators:  â¢ Operators of retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.     Sources:   https://archive.vn/rdQdH#selection-1115.0-1151.107 [Special regulations for Vienna]  https://archive.vn/MVQ1H  [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/xAEVE [Consolidated federal law - section 23 shows amendments]

Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From October 18, 2021 (until December 31, 2021), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in inpatient retirement homes and care facilities:    Visitors are only permitted to enter stationary residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.     In cases that are particularly worthy of consideration, in which visitors cannot show 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, a SARS-CoV-2 antigen test can be carried out under the supervision of a person authorized to do so by the operator of a nursing home. The negative test result must be kept available for the duration of the stay. This also applies to external service providers when there is contact with residents.    Employees may only enter inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present proof of 2G or a weekly negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.    Source: https://archive.vn/lwufm [overview of current measures in Carinthia]

Citizens and legal residents of Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Russia, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US are allowed to enter by air without the previously required special permission if they meet the following conditions:  - All passengers of 18 years and older must possess official documentation (i.e., COVID Passport) demonstrating that they have either been fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19. Additionally, a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours is required.  - All passengers between 1 and 18 years of age must possess a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours.  - No such documents are required for infants aged less than one year.    Returning Azerbaijani nationals require only a negative result from a PCR test within 72 hours prior to the flight.     Land and maritime borders remain closed, air travel is the only option to enter. A limited number of commercial and charter flights are operating to and from selected destinations. Passengers on domestic flights are no longer required to provide a test, but those flying into Baku's Heydar Aliyev International Airport (GYD) will undergo PCR tests upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211012222802/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/528426/azerbaijan-government-to-ease-certain-covid-19-related-restrictions-effective-oct-1-update-38

Following new resolutions by the Government which came into effect on October 1, all workplaces are now open, including previously closed nightclubs and discos, however, there is a need to provide a Covid Safe Ticket, which is a proof This is proof (via a QR code) of a complete vaccination (prior to 2 weeks), a negative PCR test (less than 48 hours old) or a recovery certificate (you have been cured of the virus after testing positive more than 10 days and less than 6 months before the event). This QR code can either be presented in digital form (CovidSafe app) or in print form (via MaSantÃ©). There is also a need for these establishments to guarantee sufficient air quality and ventilation, by following the protocols rigorously.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003165725/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-1709/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003173003/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/882-what-about-the-new-measures

All workplaces are allowed to be open now, including previously closed discos and nightclubs. However, concerning discos and nightclubs, they are only allowed to be opened provided that the Covid Safe Ticket is used and adequate air quality and ventilation is provided in line with stricter guidelines.     The Covid Safe Ticket is proof of full vaccination, of a recent negative PCR test or of a recovery certificate. No change in policy. No change in current policy. While restrictions in most parts of the country were removed on September 1, they still remain in place in Brussels, the capital of the nation. Wearing a mask will no longer be compulsory at indoor events gathering up to 200 people, unless local authorities decide to maintain rules to the contrary. Outdoor events gathering up to 400 people can also be organized without the need for a mask or safe distancing. Larger events can still be organized, however, these requires the Covid Safe Ticket, which indicates proof of full vaccination, a recent negative test result or the presence of antibodies following a recent coronavirus infection. Current economic measures in place have been extended to December 31, 2021.     The five socio-economic support measures that are extended until December 31, 2021 are as follows:  Temporary unemployment due to force majeure for all sectors, The simple crisis gateway right for all sectors from a loss of 65% of turnover, A monthly bonus of 25 euros for beneficiaries of integration income, a GRAPA or an ARR Financial support for rail operators (people and freight) and Maintaining the VAT rate at 6% on hydroalcoholic gel and masks    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003171205/https://www.premier.be/fr/prolongation-ciblee-des-mesures-de-soutien-economique-jusquau-31-decembre-2021

Until October 31, the Republic of Bulgaria will be conducting face-to-face group classes in language centres, educational centres and other training centres and schools with a limit of 10 per room and mandatory physical distancing. Other precautions such as mask wearing is in place.  https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Workplaces are to hold employees in remote form when possible, and will allow 50% of regular staff in the office. There will be working hours established from 7.30 until 10 oâclock when possible. Workers are required to maintain physical distance and wear masks.   https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Holding congress-conference events, seminars, training and other events are allowed at 30% capacity while participants maintain physical distance and wear masks. Team-building events are suspended/ competitions and exams are allowed at 30% capacity, not exceeding 30 participants. Mass events (festivals, fairs etc.) are suspended. Cinemas, theaters, circus and concerts are allowed at 50% while maintaining physical distance and face masks. Museums and galleries allowed one person per 8 sq. M. Visits to centres, schools and other sites for dance and music art are allowed at 30% capacity and not more than 10 people in premises. Sports games allowed without an audience, but if outside, at 30% capacity. Private character events allowed with 30 people indoors and 60 outdoors.   https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

no policy change     www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

no policy change     Public gatherings of more than 100 people in the open air and of more than 50 people in closed rooms are prohibited. A distance of 2 m must be kept. This does not apply to parliamentary sessions. Exceptionally, a maximum of 100 people may be present in theaters and cinemas, at congresses, conferences and other educational events. It is also possible to organize larger gatherings (max. 150 people indoors and max. 300 people outdoors) under specially defined conditions, ie all participants need either an antigen or PCR test, not older than 48 hours , or a certificate of their recovery, not older than six months, or a certificate of a complete vaccination. All epidemiological measures must be observed. Organizers are obliged to notify the cantonal health ministries of all planned events.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

All epidemiological measures must be observed. no policy change     Since June 11th, 2021, the 3-G rule applies to the entry of foreigners:     Submission of a negative PCR test or a rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2, which must not be older than 48 hours for arrival within Europe or 72 hours for arrival from outside Europe, calculated from the time of the swab to arrival at the border crossing  Submission of a medical certificate of recovery, valid from 14 to 180 days after illness  Submission of a certificate of a complete vaccination more than 14 days prior to entry     https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161054/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

No evidence of direct income support measures. The previous notes/entries cite imf covid-19 policy response database where the information seems to be outdated for BiH (latest update currently is from 01 July) and don't seem to be valid for the dates they were recorded. Hence coding it as a 0. (Needs to be reviewed)

no policy change     There are different debt/contract relief measures in place    Moratorium or postponement of loan repayments until June 30, 2021  Introduction of a grace period for the repayment of the capital portion of the loan obligations for loans until December 31, 2021.  Extension of the deadline for repayment of annuities  Extending the duration of one-off loans, including revolving loans and overdrafts until December 31, 2021  Approval of additional loans to overcome the current liquidity difficulties;  other measures taken by the bank to facilitate loan repayments by customers and to establish a sustainable customer business     Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises receive bank guarantees from guarantee funds forThe purpose of securing loans from commercial banks in the amount of up to 50% of the loan(for micro-businesses up to a maximum of BAM 250,000 or around EUR 125,000, for small businessesup to a maximum of BAM 1,000,000 or around EUR 500,000, for medium-sized companies up to a maximum of BAM3,000,000 or around EUR 1.5 million per application).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001170901/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/bih-foerdermassnahmen-firmen-unternehmer-covid-19.pdf

Coordinated public campaigns continues to be in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211001162826/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211001162826/https://koronavirususrpskoj.com/vladine-mjere/

no policy change     Seems to be generally available.   Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161050/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

no policy change     It is compulsory to wear a mask with a physical distance of 2 m in closed public areas. Children under 6 years of age, disabled people, athletes and people who practice sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from wearing a mask. This is what can be read on governmental sources:    "Foreign nationals without proof of a recognised vaccination seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under "Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?" are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    -Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  -Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  -Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  -Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  -Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    A detailed list of the countries exempt from restrictions and an informative graphic can be found in the link below:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210918172127/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 2000 participants outdoors and 1000 people indoors. If more than 20 people are present at the event, all those over 6 years of age must prove upon arrival that they satisfy one of the conditions listed on the archived webpage. A maximum of 20 people can meet without complying with these conditions. The organizers of mass events, which are expected to be attended by more than 1,000 people (daily), must notify the local relevant regional hygiene station no later than 5 days before the start of the event.  https://archive.ph/hV07a

Depending on level of coronavirus in country travellers are arriving from, different entry rules apply. These vary according to the level of risk (green, orange, red and dark red countries) and may involve self-isolation/quarantine, as well as PCR testing. Third-country nationals not on the list of countries with a low risk of COVID-19 are still currently prohibited from entering. There is also a ban on free movement for people arriving from abroad.   https://archive.ph/npWd2  https://archive.ph/9omJW  https://archive.ph/O6PbG

Employees, who have been quarantined, are entitled to a wage compensation of 60% of their reduced average earnings during the first 14 days. From the 15th calendar day, the sickness insurance benefit starts, paid by the employee's local District Social Security Administration. As a further incentive for the employees, a special benefit that goes above the Labour Code regulations - the "Izolacka"- has been created, a extraordinary benefit amounting up to CZK 370 a day of quarantine/isolation additionally to the wage compensation. Its main purpose is preventing the virus spread among employees and (as early as possible) eliminating an income fall.  https://archive.ph/GnvCu
Comprehensive and regularly up-dated official government coronavirus website.   https://archive.ph/Ywcda

PCR tests widely available and free of charge if indicated (ie. symptoms or possible contact with positive case). If PCR test not indicated, options to self-pay for test or may be covered by health insurance.  https://archive.ph/zqM0k
No change, comprehensive contact tracing appears to be continuing.   https://archive.ph/27Hz4

It is ordered to wear respiratory protective equipment with an efficiency of at least 94% in all interiors of buildings, with a few exceptions. It is also necessary to wear the given respiratory protection outdoors, if there is an accumulation of persons in the given area (concerts, sports matches, etc.) and several other situations. The obligation to wear a respiratory protective device with an efficiency of at least 94% does not apply during exercise and training. Face coverings are mandatory on public transport.   https://archive.ph/YTwA6  https://archive.ph/FED3x

Vaccines widely available and booster vaccines now taking place 6 months after the second dose (or 6 months after the first dose for the Janssen vaccine). The Czech Republic national vaccination programme started in December 2020 and is using the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) and AstraZeneca vaccines.   https://archive.ph/la5Ls  https://archive.ph/zhB6Z
Some restrictions and protections still in place for people visiting elderly care facilities, such as pre-visit PCR/antigen testing or proof of vaccination.   https://archive.ph/93I6w
Nationwide emergency brake has expired, and all states have allowed schools to open, though subject to some restrictions (e.g. social distancing, mask wearing)    Source:  https://archive.fo/FHCB5

In Berlin- Private meetings indoors are permitted without any limits on the amount of people attending. Outside gatherings are allowed for a maximum of 100 people. Your own children up to 14 years of age as well as vaccinated and recovered persons are not included. The permitted number of people at special celebrations is 50 persons indoors and 100 persons outdoors.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210820042720/https://www.berlin.de/corona/en/measures/

The Danish travel restrictions classify all countries and regions into four colour categories: green, yellow, orange and red. These categories determine which rules apply to you.     People coming in from countries in the red zone have the strictest guidelines requiring: a test required prior to boarding aircraft, test and isolation required after entry, with foreigners requiring a worthy purpose for entry to Denmark, and to take test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005165127/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries

There are new entry requirements in Denmark which came into effect on October 25.    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents in EU/Schengen or an OECD-country*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country without testing or self-isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark from an EU/Schengen country or within 24 hours after arrival  2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country with testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival  3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211030131742/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. You are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.    The coding was brought down to level 2, as the use of facemask or shield is not required on public transportation.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005163829/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211021140700/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

* Travellers from Poland reaching Spain since Monday, September 27, have been subject to the requirement of additional entry rules, as the Spanish Ministry of Health, Consumption and Social Welfare has added the country to its list of high-risk areas.  * At the same time, Czechiaâs regions of Moravian-Silesian and Prague, as well as Hungaryâs regions of Pest and Northern Hungary, are now part of the same list.  * Travellers reaching Spain from countries and regions in the high-risk list are subject to the requirement of proof of vaccination against COVID-19, recovery from the virus in the recent months, or negative test results for Coronavirus, in case the traveller holds neither of the two first.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004025017/https://travelbans.org/europe/spain/

The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health have examined the grounds for the validity of the national telework recommendation and propose that the telework recommendation end on 15 October. However, the Department of Health and Welfare estimates recommends the extension of the telework recommendation one month onwards, until October 31. However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates. However, this policy would be phased out on October 15    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003180557/https://stm.fi/etatyot-koronavirustilanteessa

The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health have examined the grounds for the validity of the national telework recommendation and propose that the telework recommendation end on 15 October. However, the Department of Health and Welfare estimates recommends the extension of the telework recommendation one month onwards, until October 31. However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates.    Archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003180557/https://stm.fi/etatyot-koronavirustilanteessa      https://web.archive.org/web/20211017163938/https://vm.fi/documents/10623/1121917/Et%C3%A4ty%C3%B6st%C3%A4+lis%C3%A4%C3%A4ntyv%C3%A4%C3%A4n+et%C3%A4-+ja+l%C3%A4sn%C3%A4ty%C3%B6n+yhdist%C3%A4miseen+09_2021.pdf/82d64649-ccd3-b1b0-bb63-bfb5e2edaf5d?t=1632474684713

However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates. Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003182039/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. It has been approved by Parliament and is now awaiting confirmation by the President    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923115605/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. It has been approved by Parliament and is now awaiting confirmation by the President    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923115605/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021. According to the national strategy for COVID-19 testing and tracing updated by the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health,  COVID-19 testing will primarily focus on unvaccinated people who have been exposed to the virus and are experiencing symptoms and on vaccinated people who still continue to be at risk of serious illness from COVID-19. A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. No change in policy. The use of facemasks is recommended in all parts of the country    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923121225/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

Recommendation concerning the use of face masks was updated on the 30th of September. The changes include the following:    - The recommendation is no longer based on the different phases of the coronavirus epidemic, but rather on case-by-case consideration by individuals.   - THL (Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare) recommends that masks should continue to be used especially in public indoor spaces where many people are gathered close to each other.    - THL (Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare) recommends that especially those who are not fully vaccinated should follow the mask recommendation.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003184212/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

No change in policy. The use of facemasks is recommended in all parts of the country    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923121225/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

The Finnish Institute of Health recommends the use of facemasks especially in public indoor spaces where many people are in close proximity to each other as well as those who are on their way to get tested for the coronavirus, and those who are waiting for the results of a test, if there is an urgent reason to go outside the home. Those over the age of 12 who have not received two doses of COVID-19 vaccine or who have not had a COVID-19 infection within the past six months are also specially recommended to use the facemasks.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165642/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

No change in policy. https://web.archive.org/web/20210927110636/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education     From 4 October, face masks will no longer be mandatory in primary schools in Departments where the incidence rate has stabilized below the incidence threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants for at least five days.
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211011051115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 4 October, Level 1 health protocols are implemented in schools, colleges and high schools in Departments whose incidence rate has been below the threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants over a period of 5 consecutive days. Level 2 protocols apply in all other Departments.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011051115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy, "Since Monday, October 4, 2021, the health protocol applicable in schools, colleges and high schools is level 1 / green level in departments whose incidence rate has been below the threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants over a period of 5 consecutive days. .... level 2 protocol continues to apply in the departments whose list (accessible here) is annexed to the decree of 1 June 2021" https://web.archive.org/web/20211017035459/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    The list of Departments where Level 2 protocols apply is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20211014173848/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jorf/id/JORFTEXT000044126523
No change in policy since 4 October - https://web.archive.org/web/20211022163511/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France to access cinemas, museums, cafes, restaurants, hospitals, retirement homes, medico-social institutions (except in case of emergency).  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002230938/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France to access cinemas, museums, cafes, restaurants, hospitals, retirement homes, medico-social institutions (except in case of emergency). From 30 September 2021, the "health pass" is mandatory for minors aged 12 years and two months to 17 years. https://web.archive.org/web/20211002230938/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211011051127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy, use of the Health Pass to prove vaccination status or recent recovery from infection is required to work at or enter many types of business - https://web.archive.org/web/20211015011848/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211021011402/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161920/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is mandatory in all Departments of metropolitan France in order to enter establishments and gatherings where the public is most at risk of contracting COVID-19. From 30 September, all people aged over 12 years 2 months must present a health pass for admission (reduced from 18). Venues include, but are not limited to, the following:    marquees, theatre halls, sports or cultural performance halls, conference rooms;  trade fairs and exhibition fairs;  outdoor establishments including zoological, amusement and theme parks;  stadiums, sports establishments, swimming pools, gyms;  casinos, gambling halls and bowling alleys;  outdoor sit/stand festivals;  cinemas and theatres;  monuments, museums and exhibition halls;  libraries, media libraries (excluding university and specialized libraries, BPI);  sports competitions;  other events, cultural, sporting, recreational or festive, organized in the public space or in a place open to the public and likely to give rise to a control of the access of persons;  religious establishments for events not of a religious nature;  ships and boats, such as cruise ships;  discos, clubs and dancing bars;  funfairs, from a threshold of 30 stands or attractions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001161920/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

RT-PCR and lateral flow tests remain generally available, but the cost of such tests are no longer universally covered by health insurance as of 15 October.     Prime Minister Jean Castex announced that "It is no longer legitimate to pay excessively for comfort tests at taxpayers' expense. But tests will continue to be reimbursed on medical grounds, either without a prescription for people already vaccinated or on prescription for others. We also want to keep it free for minors. The logic is to reimburse tests related to truly medical reasons, and to continue to encourage vaccination."    Testing costs will be covered by insurance for people:     - having a complete vaccination schedule (or a contraindication to vaccination)  - minors  - identified for "contact tracing" by the Health Insurance agency  - during collective screening campaigns (ARS, schools, etc.)  - symptomatic on medical prescription  - with a recovery certificate of less than six months    Tests required to obtain a Health Pass become chargeable as of 15 October.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211020113443/https://www.gouvernement.fr/fin-de-la-gratuite-systematique-des-tests-covid-19

"In indoor public spaces (shops, offices, schools etc) and on public transport you must wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth. You donât need to wear a mask in places where a health pass is required (although local authorities may review this). If you are outside you do not need to wear a mask except in places where social distancing is not possible (queues, open-air markets, railway stations, etc.)."    Masks are also required in schools, although this requirement will be relaxed on 4 October if the COVID-19 incidence rate is <50 per 100,000 inhabitants within a Department for a period of 5 days. https://web.archive.org/web/20210925000147/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older.     Vaccination is mandatory for the following groups from 15 September 2021:   - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  s- taff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.    Booster vaccines are recommended for people aged 65 and over, people with comorbidities that increase risk of severe forms of Covid-19. A vaccination booster campaign us underway to promote a third vaccination for residents of nursing homes and LTCU, people over 80, those at very high risk of severe Covid-19, and immunocompromised people.     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011053023/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older, and is mandatory for all staff working with vulnerable people (including home help staff, all employees of medical institutions, firefighters - full list available at archived link.)    Booster vaccines are recommended for people aged 65+ and people with comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19.     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017035752/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older, and is mandatory for all staff working with vulnerable people (including home help staff, all employees of medical institutions, firefighters - full list available at archived link.)    Pfizer-BioNTech booster vaccines are recommended for people who received their last vaccination 6 months ago, or 4 weeks after vaccination with the Janssen vaccine, for the following groups of people:    - People aged 12-17 who are immunocompromised or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19    - People aged 18 to 64 who:   -- have been vaccinated with the Janssem vaccine  -- are living with compromised immune systems or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19, and those who live with them  -- health care professionals, home assistants, transport staff working with vulnerable people  -- firefighters    - people aged 65 or over     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211022163823/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

The Chief Medical Officer will contact you if you have been in direct contact with an infected person. If you have had direct contact with a person who has been infected with COVID-19 you will quarantine for at least 10 days, pending a negative test result. No changes according to the Georgian government website: "Land borders of Georgia are open from June 1, 2021 in line with a decision made by the Inter-Agency Coordination Council. Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004123311/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

In the FAQ of the official Georgian website the definition of a high-risk contact is given with the following measures to take:   - begin self-isolation (at home, in corresponding hotel) during 12 days after the contact;    - Watch your health condition; if you identify symptoms of COVID-19, call 112 or contact directly your family doctor. After that you will be redirected to testing.    - If COVID-19 is confirmed, a doctor will make a decision on homecare or placing you in clinic based on your condition and symptoms;    - If the result is negative, continue observation of self-isolation rules. If none of suspicious symptoms revealed during self-isolation period, the self-isolation ends at 12th day after beginning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004130025/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/

Greece will impose a nighttime curfew and ban music at bars, cafes and restaurants in Thessaloniki, its second biggest city, following an increase in COVID-19 cases, the government said on Thursday.  https://archive.is/RZs0D

https://archive.is/7s8Uj  Greece will, starting on Saturday, begin a two-week test of lifting some pandemic restrictions in regions where coronavirus cases have been the highest â but for the most part, only vaccinated people will be able to enjoy the heightened freedom.

no policy change     Effective Sept. 13, all unvaccinated workers both in the public and private sectors will need to take a COVID-19 test once a week at their own expense. Those employed in industries that involve direct contact with large numbers of people, such as tourism and catering, will need to take two COVID-19 rapid tests a week.    Workers will need to upload their test results to the relevant government website and carry printed proof of a negative test to be allowed admission to their workplaces. Persons who test positive will receive further instructions on additional testing and self-isolation. The new regulation will also allow employers to demand proof of vaccination from employees who work in close proximity to other staff. Authorities have indicated that the cost of rapid tests will be set at EUR 10.    /web/20210919211330/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/517001/greece-authorities-plan-to-tighten-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-starting-sept-13-update-71

no policy change   At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    /web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

no policy change     Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  As of May 14, 2021, Greek authorities lifted prior restrictions on travel between regions in Greece.  Individuals traveling by land in continental Greece are strongly recommended to self-test before departure, but are not required to do so.  All passengers traveling to Greek islands by air or ferry must provide the following documents, depending on their age group, as described on the GreeceHealthFirst.gr website:  Adults (18 and over)  Proof of full vaccination at least 14 days prior to travel; or  A negative PCR test no older than 72 hours; or  A negative antigen (rapid) test no older than 48 hours; or  Documentation by a health care professional of recovery from COVID-19 within the previous 2-9 months.  Minors (aged 12 to 17):  Any of the documents listed above for adults; or  A self-test taken no more than 24 hours before boarding. Self-test results must be reported either electronically via the https://self-testing.gov.gr/ website or by printing and filling out the Self-Test Declaration form.  Children under the age of 12 are not required to provide COVID-19 documentation for travel within Greece.  Passengers traveling to Greek islands must fill in the Pre-boarding Health Declaration questionnaire (on their cell phone/tablet or on paper) within 24 hrs before their embarkation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210911002130/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 5 August, there are additional gathering restrictions in Sisimiut, Upernavik, Upernavik district and Aasiaat. A maximum of 20 persons may gather in these geographic areas, for both outdoor and indoor arrangements, events, and other public activities. Some public establishments may be required to limit access to fewer than 20 persons, depending on the size of their area. This is valid through 31 October.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315224140/https://blog.wego.com/greenland-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. A face mask or shield is not required when using public transportation. You are advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital.    However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210424102045/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/europa-utazasi-tanacsok?dania

From 22 October 2021, further restrictions will be lifted, including limits on numbers attending:    - Weddings  - Organised indoor and outdoor group events  - Religious or civil ceremonies  - Nightclubs and other hospitality can fully reopen with some restrictions in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211024162025/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html

By law, you have to wear a face covering: on public transport, in shops, shopping centres and other indoor settings, including cinemas and salons, in banks, posts offices and credit unions    You should also wear a face covering: when staying 2 metres apart from people is difficult, in healthcare settings - this includes hospitals, GP surgeries, care settings, nursing homes and dental practices, when visiting anyone who is more at risk from COVID-19 (coronavirus) - such as people aged 70 or over or people who are medically vulnerable, in crowded workplaces, places of worship and in busy outdoor spaces where a lot of people gather.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004124919/https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/covid19/preventing-the-spread/when-to-wear-face-covering/

From 28 August 2021 and will apply up to and including 17 September 2021  The maximum number of people allowed in the same location is 200 persons, with certain restrictions, both in public and private locations, outdoors and indoors  At all workplaces and when performing other professional activities, people with no close link between them must keep a distance of one metre from each other  Various professional activities, e.g. shops, restaurants, performing arts, etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210913095938/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210914071118/https://www.adnkronos.com/scuola-e-obbligo-green-pass-primo-giorno-regole-in-classe_2qTRFcm7k4wipUZEQDtKWe  http://web.archive.org/web/20211004161458/https://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/skuola/universita-come-si-torna-in-facolta-le-regole-per-lanno-accademico-2021-22_39031586-202102k.shtml

Discotheques will remain closed until (excl.) Oct 11th.  On Oct 11th discos will be reopening with a max capacity of 50% for indoor ballrooms, 75% for outdoor ballrooms. Guests will have to hold a green pass to enter discos.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008153454/https://www.adnkronos.com/capienza-cinema-stadi-teatri-e-riapertura-discoteche-cosa-cambia-e-da-quando_18fr37pqYLhyNEfqkf6SIN    Gyms, restaurants, pools that don't have outdoor facilities can only host guests holding a green pass, they are therefore virtually closed for those who don't have one.  Furthermore starting Oct 15th most workplaces will be virtually closed for those who don't hold a green pass.  No substantial difference for Yellow zones: the only difference is for restaurants, where the number of guests at the same table is 4 for yellow zones for both inside and outside dining.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210902083708/https://www.fanpage.it/politica/la-differenza-tra-le-restrizioni-in-zona-bianca-e-in-zona-gialla-cosa-cambia-e-quali-sono-le-regole/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211006161014/https://www.governo.it/it/articolo/domande-frequenti-sulle-misure-adottate-dal-governo/15638

On Oct 11th discos have reopened with a max capacity of 50% for indoor ballrooms, 75% for outdoor ballrooms. Guests will have to hold a green pass to enter discos.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008153454/https://www.adnkronos.com/capienza-cinema-stadi-teatri-e-riapertura-discoteche-cosa-cambia-e-da-quando_18fr37pqYLhyNEfqkf6SIN  Gyms, restaurants, pools that don't have outdoor facilities can only host guests holding a green pass, they are therefore virtually closed for those who don't have one.  capacity for some businesses has been revised, cinemas for instance can now be at 100% capacity as all persons entering the facilities need to have a green pass.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211013221834/https://www.adnkronos.com/riaperture-e-green-pass-regioni-aggiornano-linee-guida-ristoranti-e-discoteche_DG69O2s7yevEPfo7EAix3
