No change as per previous update.    Quote (translated):  "The decree on the work of educational organizations in the 2021/2022 academic year during the Covid-19 pandemic was signed by the chief state sanitary doctor of Kazakhstan, Yerlan Kiyasov.  The decree says:  Allow training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format in educational institutions of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation.  Akims of regions, the cities of Almaty, Nur-Sultan, Shymkent, the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan, heads of educational organizations of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation to provide training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format under the following conditions:  compliance with sanitary and anti-epidemic measures;  100% vaccination of teachers and staff (with the exception of persons with permanent medical contraindications who have recovered from Covid-19);  implementation of the Ashyq application at the entrance to the organization (registration by the QR code of teachers, staff, parents, visitors, students aged 18 and over);  observance of the mask regime;  providing a sufficient number of recirculators, sanitizers, skin antiseptics, disinfectants and detergents;  increasing the frequency of cleaning and disinfection of premises;  compliance with the requirements for wet cleaning and disinfection of premises, for the mode of ventilation and disinfection of air in premises;  daily "input" filter (thermometry with a non-contact thermometer) for teachers, staff and students;  a ban on holding mass events (cultural, educational, extracurricular and parental meetings, and others);  a ban on holding events in organizations of preschool and secondary education with the unification of groups and classes;  the abolition of the office training system, with the exception of laboratory, practical classes;  separation of students in primary, middle and senior classes (taking into account the maximum opportunity for the time of the beginning of classes)."    Archived link: https://archive.vn/m1MWC

Quote 1: "A wide variety of businesses â including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities â are open, in some cases subject to restrictions on hours of operation subject to capacity limitations.   However, some regional and local governments periodically impose restrictions in response to increases in the infection rate."    Archived link 1:  https://archive.vn/FCLxq    Quote 2: "Turkestan and Zhambyl regions are classified as green zones. The following measures remain in place in these locations:    Public transportation and nonessential businesses are operating; all establishments must operate at reduced capacity and enforce social distancing."  "Authorities recommend that employees work from home."    "Almaty (excluding Almaty city), East Kazakhstan, North Kazakhstan, West Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, Mangistau, and Shymkent regions are classified as yellow zones. "Almaty (excluding Almaty city), East Kazakhstan, North Kazakhstan, West Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, Mangistau, and Shymkent regions are classified as yellow zones. Quote: "Turkestan and Zhambyl regions are classified as green zones. The following measures remain in place in these locations:    Public transportation and nonessential businesses are operating; all establishments must operate at reduced capacity and enforce social distancing."    "Almaty (excluding Almaty city), East Kazakhstan, North Kazakhstan, West Kazakhstan, Kyzylorda, Mangistau, and Shymkent regions are classified as yellow zones. The following additional measures are typically enforced in yellow zones:    Public transport operates from 06:00-23:00 Monday-Saturday and is suspended on Sundays." As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system "    Archived link:  https://archive.vn/FCLxq

Quote: "International Travel RestrictionsVisa-free travel remains suspended. Authorities have also suspended 72-hour visa-free stays for Chinese and Indian nationals. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited.    International arrivals must provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry into Kazakhstan or a vaccination certificate. This restriction does not apply to diplomats, aircrew, train crews, ship crews, and cross-border workers; however, freight truck drivers must provide a negative test. Returning Kazakh nationals who do not produce a negative test or vaccine certificate upon arrival will be tested and placed in quarantine for at least three days. All symptomatic individuals will be hospitalized, while asymptomatic individuals must self-isolate for a further 12 days."    Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210926020833/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526306/kazakhstan-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-entry-restrictions-as-of-sept-20-update-47

Any gathering of more than 300 people is prohibited. Every gathering of 11 up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and keep a minimum distance of 2 meters. Meetings between 11 and 300 people can be held using the CovidCheck system upon prior notification. https://web.archive.org/web/20211005075331/https://covid19.public.lu/de/hygienemassnahmen/versammlungen.html

Any gathering exceeding 2,000 people is prohibited except they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate.  Any gathering between 11 and up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres. For gatherings of between 51 and 2,000 people, seating must also be provided. Gatherings of 11 and up to 2.000 people can be held, with prior notification, under the CovidCheck system. https://archive.vn/0SeRo

For meetings at home or at private events, the general meeting rules apply. There are no restrictions or hygiene measures to be observed for private celebrations with up to 10 guests. For groups of 11 or more, masks must be worn and a distance of 2 meters between people must be maintained. Seats must be allocated for groups of 51 or more. https://web.archive.org/web/20211005075331/https://covid19.public.lu/de/hygienemassnahmen/versammlungen.html

For private parties of up to 10 guests, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed. For 11 or more people, masks must be worn and a distance of 2 metres between people must be observed. Private events with more than 10 people, without the need to wear a mask, the 2-metre distance between people or the obligation to assign seats, you must opt for the CovidCheck system. https://archive.vn/0SeRo

Wearing a mask is compulsory at all times in public transport, with the exception of the driver if a distance of two metres can be respected, or if a partition separates him from the passengers. https://web.archive.org/web/20211005075300/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

Schools and universities could be only attained with Covid-19 certificate or a negative test. Pupils who are vaccinated after the contact with an infected person is not obliged to is in a quarantine (only the test is required after 7 days).

As of October 11th Latvia enter the state of emergency, provisionally for 3 months.   Kindergardens and schools will continue to educate pupils in person regardless of vaccination status. Universities are allowed to give classes in person only to people with valid Covid-19 certificate (tests not allowed). Meanwhile, extra curriculum activities will face more strict restrictions. Education that is not defined as mandatory can happen in person in groups only among people from one school/class. Otherwise, classes should happen outside (maximum number of people limited to 20) or on an individual basis.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211014095000/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/aktualites/11-october-emergency-situation-declared-latvia-three-months  https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

As of October 21 Latvia started the period of strengthened security measures.  Pupils' holidays has been extended until 29 October 2021.  - From 1 November 2021, 1st to 3rd grade pupils will study in person, strictly observing the general safety measures.   - From 1 November 2021, 4th to 12th grade pupils will study remotely.  - From 15 November 2021, the learning process for pupils of all grades will be able to take place in person.  Kindergartens operate strictly subject to epidemiological safety requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Services in person are allowed only for persons with Covid-19 certificate or a negative test. I still code a 1 for C2, because together with this regulation there are more availability to do an antigen test (now it is easier to do a test at all medical institutions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20211004053129/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/apstiprina-rudens-epidemiologisko-regulejumu

In the private sector: the employer evaluates the responsibilities, specifics and circumstances of each employee's work, determining the risk of infection and the spread of infection. Persons who, according to the assessment, are not exposed to the risk of infection and do not cause it to others may perform work tasks without a valid vaccination, recovery or testing certificate. In public sector people without Covid-19 certificate will not be able to perform their duties.   Indoors restaurants, services and retail trade (except essential products) can be used only by people with valid Covid-19 certificate (with vaccine or recent recovery, tests are not allowed). Unvaccinated people can get meals outdoors as takeaway.     Indoors vaccinated people can only make purchases in these points of sale:       - grocery stores (with foodstuff being 70% of the assortment);       - pharmacies (including veterinary);       - opticians;       - pet food stores;       - press outlets;        - hygiene goods stores (with hygiene items being 70% of the assortment);       - telecommunications goods and service providers;       - fuel stations.    On weekends shopping centers are closed for everybody. Only essential stores are allowed to operate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Only essential trade and services are allowed to operate during lockdown period.     Work must take place remotely.  - Vaccinated* or those who have started vaccination can work on-site with a negative Covid-19 test if they are employed in industries of very high importance to the society or if the nature of work does not permit working remotely.  - Vaccinated on-site workers can be tested regularly by the employer.  - Every day on-site workers submit self-certification that there has been no known/deliberate contact with the infected person and they do not have symptoms of respiratory infectious diseases.    There is an obligation for people who are work in public sectors to get vaccinated otherwise they might be suspended from work.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
No changes.

Events can be attended only by people with Covid-19 certificate (no tests allowed). Face masks are required by everyone.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

- Public events are not held.  - Private events can take place within one household at the place of residence.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
No changes.

Unvaccinated people can gather maximum 20 people outdoors. Otherwise, no restrictions for people with Covid-19 certificates.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

- Representatives of two households may meet to:      - provide care for a person;      - provide support to a single person (living alone in a household);      - parents whose minor children live in another household can meet with the children (unless isolation, home quarantine, self-isolation is required).     Exemptions on number of people allowed for certain ceremonies like baptism, marriage, funerals, etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
From 25 October 2021, public transport service providers receiving a grant from state or municipal funds may not grant fare reductions to adults who do not have a vaccination/recovery certificate.

Municipality and public transport service providers receiving grants from municipalities do not apply fare reductions. Urban and suburban public transport operates without exceeding 50% of its capacity. The capacity of regional and interurban public transport is up to 80% (85% if it is required to pick up passengers at stops outside the regional importance routes).  https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Every resident must stay at his/her place of residence from 20:00 to 5:00 in the period from 21 October to 14 November.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
No changes.

- When arriving in Latvia from low-risk countries, a test must be performed before starting the trip, self-isolation does not have to be observed.  - When arriving from high-risk countries, a test must be performed before entering Latvia, as well as self-isolation must be observed upon arrival.  - When arriving from high-risk third countries, a test must be performed before and after entering Latvia, as well as self-isolation must be observed. In this case, an important reason for entering Latvia is required.
No changes to policy.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211025052446/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Moldovan authorities established new public health measures to limit the spread of COVID-19 infection at all public events and gatherings, both indoor and outdoor.  Anyone over the age of 18 eating in a restaurant or cafÃ© or attending any show, concert, festival, theater, cinema, concert hall, nightclub, dance floor, etc., must present one of the following documents: 1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004190732/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"Starting on October 1st, students are not required to use masks in school playgrounds (...) Masks are still mandatory in the classroom and throughout the building for students from middle school onwards.  When a positive case appears at the school, the prime minister referred the decision to the Directorate-General of Health (DGS) (...) the DGS confirmed that it is ready to review the two standards related to contact tracing and prophylactic isolation. These should be published within the next few hours or days."  Sources: https://archive.vn/lqDai https://archive.vn/lxs1q

no change in policy  see here: https://www.web.archive.org/web/20211025180747/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/desconfinamento/  https://www.web.archive.org/web/20211025181419/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Portugal is in a countrywide State of Alert. Under the State of Alert, the Portuguese Government can impose obligatory quarantine for individuals infected with COVID-19 and individuals deemed by health officials to require special medical observation. The Government of Portugal announced a phased deconfinement plan for the gradual lifting of restrictions based on the overall vaccination rate in Portugal. The plan, implemented in three phases, is in Phase 3.    Phase 3: Beginning October 1    Restaurants, bars, disco, cafÃ©s continue to function under normal hours at full capacity (with no maximum number of people per group, both indoors and terraces)  Max capacity at commercial/retail spaces increased (venue dependent)  Cultural events/shows continue to function under normal hours at full capacity    Presentation  COVID EU Digital Certificate will no longer be necessary to access:  - group classes in gyms, spas and spas  - restaurants  - tourist establishments or local accommodation  - gambling establishments and casinos    Presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate remains necessary to access:  - bars and clubs    Masks - Indoors: Mandatory while using public transportation, elder care facilities, hospitals, theaters, large event spaces such as stadiums and arena, public spaces such as shopping centers, and supermarkets.     Sources: https://archive.vn/gKHok  https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: All work areas are now open. However, bars and nightclubs require the use of the covid certificate, so the coding remains unchanged to reflect closures for people without a covid certificate exemption.
Policy remains unchanged.  Source: https://archive.vn/g7A6F

"The prime minister, AntÃ³nio Costa, announced this Thursday the lifting of several restrictions, with effect from 1 October.    (...) Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."    Measures that will come into force on October 1st include;    - Restaurants with no maximum limit of people per group;  - Mandatory mask in theaters and events;  - The digital certificate is still required for major cultural, sports or corporate events;  - End of capacity limits, namely for weddings and baptisms and cultural shows and popular festivals. AntÃ³nio Costa explained that spectators will be required to present a digital certificate in order to access "major cultural events" (...) On the use of masks in shows, AntÃ³nio Costa explained that it will be mandatory "whenever there is no distance of two meters between people"."    According to the Director General of Health "To access to cultural events that are held with capacity for over 1,000 spectators indoors (rooms or similar) and over 5,000 spectators in an open environment (outdoor events), the presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative SARS-COV-2 negative test is required."    Sources: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1  https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: Coded 2 to reflect the ban on the participation of those people without a proof of negative COVID-19 test/COVID-19 vaccination certificate in major events with 1000+ people.
Policy remains unchanged.  Source: https://archive.vn/g7A6F

"Before boarding, all passengers must present a certificate with a negative result of one of the following tests for screening of SARS-CoV-2 (...) Third country nationals without legal residency in Portugal will be refused entry if they do not hold a valid negative COVID-19 test or a recognised vaccination or recovery certificate.    (...) in addition to the COVID-19 test, passengers arriving from the following countries must undergo a 14 days mandatory quarantine in their homes, or in the places indicated by the health authorities and pre-register before travelling.?  India, Nepal, South Africa    (...) Passengers who have an EU-issued COVID-19 digital green certificate (EU DCC) or a non EU-issued certificate stating full vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.    The following passengers are allowed to transit through, enter and exit from Portugal:    European Union nationals, nationals of the of Schengen associated countries and their family members  Third-country nationals with legal residence in a European Union member state  Third-country nationals travelling for professional reasons, study, family reunification, health or humanitarian reasons  Nationals and legal residents of the following countries, provided that they are arriving on a direct flight or transiting only through the international area of any other airport:  Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Jordan, Kuwait, Macau, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Ukraine, United States of America, United Kingdom, Uruguay  Passengers holding valid EU Digital COVID Certificate or vaccination/recovery certificate issued by a non-EU country that accepts the EU Digital COVID Certificate are allowed to travel to Portugal for non-essential purposes.    Arriving to Portugal by Land  No restrictions of entrance.    Arriving to Portugal by Sea  Same rules as arriving by air apply.    Source: https://archive.vn/6ZQFt    Note: Coded 2 due to the fact that there are no entry restrictions in land borders.

"The new rules for combating the pandemic were published this Wednesday in DiÃ¡rio da RepÃºblica, in a decree-law that does not change, for now, any social support in force (...) September 7 - "The Energy Services Regulatory Authority (ERSE) considers that a "situation of exceptionality" remains due to the Covid-19 pandemic and therefore defends the extension, until December 31, 2021, of the prohibition of cuts in the supply of electricity and gas (...) However, this only applies in situations of unemployment, loss of household income (equal to or greater than 20%) or infection with coronavirus (...) The regulator published this Tuesday in DiÃ¡rio da RepÃºblica a regulation approving exceptional measures (...) in exceptional cases, the regulator extends the obligation of suppliers to allow customers to pay the bills in instalements. This applies to customers affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, but also to all the others."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210910115439/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/09/07/cortes-de-luz-e-gas-proibidos-ate-ao-fim-do-ano-apenas-para-casos-excecionais/    June 18 - "The Parliament approved this Tuesday the extension of the moratorium on bank loans, which ended in the end of September, until December 31st in the component of capital reimbursement, for individuals and companies in sectors especially affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.     (...) The extension of this regime applies, however, only to "individuals and companies that develop their activity in sectors especially affected by the Covid-19 pandemic (...) as is the case with the accommodation, catering, culture and transportation sectors, among others".    Source: https://archive.vn/ThZpE    Note: Code remains unchanged because, even though the majority of the aforementioned measures target specific groups of the population, a 2 better represents the situation - taking into consideration that 3+ are currently in place.

Visitors must:    - present EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative test  - carry out the visits at a previously scheduled time and with a limited time (not to exceed 90 minutes)  - respect the limit of visitor per resident or user at a time  - respect physical distance from users, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene  - use a mask, preferably surgical, during the entire period of stay in the institution  - do not take personal items, food or other products  - do not walk around the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities  - ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with airing conditions  - visitors who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the local health authority if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms  - prioritise communication with the user via video call or telephone  - if visitors have signs or symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 or have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days they should refrain from conducting the visit    Source: https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: Code remains unchanged since the aforementioned measures apply to all visitors (who must present a proof of negative test/vaccination certificate - i.e. there are no exceptions)

The Recovered - Vaccinated - Tested rule mandatory for all employees  The Government ordinance stipulates that the Recovered - Vaccinated â Tested rule (RVT rule*) must be met by all employees as well as all users of services or activities, except in cases of the emergency supply of basic necessities of life, the provision of public order, security and defence, emergency medical assistance and protection and rescue, urgent healthcare services, urgent procedures involving social and family issues, urgent personal assistance, and protection and rescue.    Employees  The RVT rule must be met for the duration of work by all employees and persons who work for an employer on another legal basis, or are self-employed. The requirements of the RVT rule do not have to be met while a person is working from home.    Verification of meeting the RVT rule shall be organised by the responsible persons carrying out or organising the work.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211019144650/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Cultural events and festivals are permitted at 75% capacity with social distancing and face masks being used.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920080332/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/coronavirus

Gatherings of more than 50 people at organised public events and assemblies is permitted indoors and outdoors in accordance with the Public Assembly Act and when the organiser is known.    The attendees must meet the RVT rule. Attendees under the age of 15 are exempt from this condition.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210909212140/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/europa-utazasi-tanacsok?szlovenia

Mandatory face masks complying with RVT rule and registration of the event  http://web.archive.org/web/20211019144650/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Gathering (socialising) is permitted to groups of up to 50 persons only, unless they are close family members or share the same household.    Indoor and outdoor public assemblies and events  Gatherings of more than 50 people at organised public events and assemblies is permitted indoors and outdoors in accordance with the Public Assembly Act and when the organiser is known.    The attendees must meet the RVT rule. Attendees under the age of 15 are exempt from this condition.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211009145716/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Gathering of people (socialising)  Gathering (socialising) is permitted to groups of up to 50 persons only, unless they are close family members or share the same household.    Indoor and outdoor public assemblies and events  Gatherings of more than 50 people at organised public events and assemblies is permitted indoors and outdoors in accordance with the Public Assembly Act and when the organiser is known.    The attendees must meet the RVT rule. Attendees under the age of 15 are exempt from this condition.    Protective face masks are mandatory:    in all indoor public spaces or premises,  in all outdoor public spaces or premises where the minimum 1.5-metre social distancing cannot be attained.  Protective face masks are not mandatory:    in outdoor public spaces or premises for members of the same household and where the minimum 1.5-metre social distancing is attained,  in all outdoor public spaces or premises if the RVT rule is observed.  At the entry to an event or an assembly, the organiser of the public event or assembly must determine whether all attendees of the event or the assembly meet the RVT rule. A person who fails to meet this condition is not permitted to attend the event or assembly. The organiser is obliged to inform the attendees of the event or the assembly that observance of the RVT rule is mandatory for attending the event or assembly by placing a written notification in a visible location.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211019144650/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

http://web.archive.org/web/20211025060359/https://www.slovenia.info/en/plan-your-trip/all-you-need-to-know-for-a-healthy-and-safe-vacation-in-slovenia  http://web.archive.org/web/20211025061920/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/  10 day quarantine for unvaccinated  If none of the documents can be submitted, a 10-day quarantine is required. A person ordered to quarantine at home upon entering Slovenia may end quarantine early by producing a negative PCR test for the presence of SARS-CoV-2. Testing may only be performed from the fifth day of home quarantine.      A foreigner who is not a resident of Slovenia will be allowed to enter Slovenia and ordered to undergo a 10-day quarantine only if they can prove beyond any doubt that they have a guaranteed place to quarantine. Otherwise, they are denied entry. It is not possible to quarantine in tourist accommodations.
Government providing support to formal workers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004084021/http://www.interregeurope.eu/oss/news/news-article/11994/slovenian-measures-to-fight-covid-crisis/

Partial reimbursement of wage compensations paid to workers by employers who are temporarily unable to provide workers with work as a result of the epidemic or because of force majeure  Partial exemption from social security contributions,  exemption from pension and disability insurance contributions for working employees  reimbursement of compensations paid to workers by employers due to temporary absence from work because of illness or injury  exceptional state aid for the legitimates (certain self-employed workers, religious employees, head of the (agriculture) holding farmer) in the form of universal basic income (UBI) in the amount of EUR 350 for March and EUR 700 for April  and EUR 700 for May;  social contribution and social security exemption for April and May for the legitimates (certain self-employed workers, religious employees, head of the (agriculture) holding farmer).    The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups.      Subsidying <50% is more common than >50%, therefore I marked "1"  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011195329/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Accordingly, in early June, each adult in Slovenia received a â¬ 200 voucher (â¬ 50 per child) to be spent in accommodation in Slovenia, as a measure to support tourism. The amount earmarked is â¬ 345 million and can be used until end-2020.On June 28, the government adopted an emergency bill to address the surge in new cases, including an extension of the furlough support scheme until end-September and a legal basis for the tracking app.    Further support in the Fall to address the second wave. The authorities rolled out a fifth COVID-19 stimulus package on September 30 to mitigate the effects of the crisis and extend certain existing measures until end-2020. These include measures (i) to extend furlough funding and full pay compensation until the end of 2020, (ii) to support self-employed and micro-companies through monthly income compensation, (iii) support employees who have to be quarantined with full salary replacement, and (iv) further support families, with parents receiving 80 percent of their salaries in case of school quarantine. In addition, â¬ 95 million from the existing resources in the COVID-19 fund will serve to fund microloans and loans for R&D and innovation. On November 11, the government announced the sixth anti-crisis package, estimated at â¬ 1 billion and including an extension of the furlough scheme, compensation to businesses that are losing revenue due to the pandemic and partial or full waivers of rent payments for renters of state and local governments property. Most measures that have been already introduced will remain in place till the end of the year with the possibility for further extension. In end-December 2020, parliament passed the seventh anti-crisis package, introducing some changes to the eligibility criteria for support and provided for additional solidarity payments. On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extended the furlough till April (subsequently extended to end-June) and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211025063225/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available at Slovenian government institutions as well as private clinics.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 15-30 euro; cost for PCR is around 95 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.  Tests are not available at the U.S. Embassy.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211010150551/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A, B, C. Pfizer/Biotech vaccine, AstraZeneca, Moderna and Janssen.    Increased vaccine supply has accelerated the vaccination of the population. Slovenia has administered at least 1,324,824 doses of COVID vaccines so far. Assuming every person needs 2 doses, thatâs enough to have vaccinated about 31.7% of the countryâs population. By the end of June, Slovenia should therefore reach the target of 60-per cent vaccination coverage of the entire population.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210927191900/https://www.gov.si/en/news/?year=2021&month=9&day=0&nrOfItems=100

On March 18, the government introduced several other measures such as priority while visiting grocery shops between 8 AM and 10 AM for elderly people and other vulnerable groups (those with disabilities and pregnant women) [30], which entered into force on March 30 [31]. On the same day, the government also introduced a ban on leaving oneâs home municipality (these are 212 small territorial areas with a median number of inhabitants of around 5,000; the smallest two municipalities have some 350 inhabitants) [32]. There were some exceptions, such as crossing over the boundaries of a municipality to visit family members in need of protection, assistance, support, or nursing care. Crossing between municipalities was also allowed for the purpose of visiting, e.g., grocery shops or pharmacies, if none existed in oneâs own municipality. The reason for moving between municipalities had to be proved with appropriate documents.    For the elderly population and those with physical disabilities, the introduced measure about visiting grocery stores was insufficient because they were unable to complete their shopping by 10 AM. Especially vulnerable were individuals whose social supporters all came from other municipalities. Therefore, representatives of different governmental and non-governmental organizations suggested extending the opening hours for vulnerable groups [33], as happened on April 4 [34], allowing them to also visit grocery stores in the last hour of opening.  https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0247993

Restrictions on public events such as dance events, religious gatherings, cultural/sporting events, and demonstrations vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Demonstrations: 1800 people  - Sports grounds:  no limitation    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

Since the 29th of September there are no more restrictions or recommendations that limit the possibility to accomodate guests (restaurants, concerts, ...)    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004082559/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/national-general-guidelines-to-reduce-the-spread-of-covid-19/

Restrictions on gatherings vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Party venue for private party: 50 people  - Other space or indoor area for private party (e.g. a bus, boat or tent): 50 people  - Party, private in home: Larger parties should be avoided and outdoors is preferable to indoors. Private parties in homes and gardens are not subject to legally binding rules.  - Funerals are always allowed to have 20 participants. This also applies if, for example, requirements for distance between parties would otherwise mean that there could not be so many.    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

Swedish citizens or foreign nationals who are registered or who have the right of residence can enter Sweden. An RT-PCR test is recommended on return for those who have travelled outside the Nordic countries, unless they have been fully vaccinated.    Foreign nationals entering from the EU/EEA must present a a vaccination certificate, test certificate, or certificate that they have recovered from COVID-19. The requirements do not apply if travelling from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway. A negative COVID-19 test may be a maximum of 72 hours old upon entry. Children under the age of 18 are exempt from the requirement for vaccination certificates, test certificates and certificates of recovery from COVID-19.    A ban is in place for non-essential travel to Sweden from outside the EU/EEA. The ban applies to foreign nationals entering from outside the EU/EEA and is valid until 31 August 2021. Some persons with particularly urgent needs or who are to perform the necessary functions in Sweden may be exempted from the ban. Foreign nationals who meet the requirements for exemptions can enter Sweden if they can present a maximum 72-hour certificate of negative COVID-19 testing.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211004090247/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Tuesday, October 19, travellers from the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain can enter Sweden restriction-free, regardless of their vaccination status, the Swedish Ministry of Justice has announced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211019072938/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-removes-entry-ban-for-all-travellers-from-uae-bahrain/

Government support for short-time working has been extended until 30 September, under which regulations an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. In Sweden, adolescents aged 16 and over are now also being offered vaccination against COVID-19. Children aged 12-15 years with an increased risk of severe viral infections are also being offered vaccination.    Vaccination is largely available even for non Swedish citizens in specific cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094003/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/children-and-adolescents--information-about-vaccination-against-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094027/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/cf2fc83a0b98452cb45cd4c4c63120e9/vem-erbjuds-vaccination-covd-19-engelska.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094054/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/

Groups:    Pregnant women  If you are pregnant, you can get vaccinated throughout your pregnancy. However, the Public Health Agency recommends that vaccination be given after pregnancy week 12, unless there are other reasons. For example, you may have a medical risk factor such as obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes or are over 35 years of age.    Most people who become ill with Covid-19 experience mild symptoms of illness and do not need to seek medical care. But pregnant women have a slightly higher risk of becoming seriously ill. Vaccination against Covid-19 is recommended for all pregnant women, as the vaccines provide good protection against serious illness and reduce the risk of early delivery.    About pregnancy and vaccines from the Public Health Agency    Children and young people   All people, twelve years and older, are offered Covid-19 vaccination.    Each region determines how they handle consent when vaccinating minors. Some regions send a consent form in connection with the booking, others make a maturity assessment at the time of vaccination.     The Swedish Public Health Agency has decided to suspend the use of Modernaâs Spikevax vaccine for everyone born in 1991 or later.    COVID-19 vaccination for children aged 12â15, The Public Health Agency of Sweden    Those with immunodeficiency  If you are over 18 years of age and have a severely impaired immune system due to a disease or medical treatment, it is recommended that you take an extra dose of Covid-19 vaccine. It is your treating doctor who will prescribe the extra dose after an individual assessment.    The Elderly  The Swedish Public Health Agency ("FolkhÃ¤lsomyndigheten") recommends that people at increased risk of severe Covid-19 be offered a vaccine booster. This includes those who live in care homes, those with home health care or home care and everyone who is 80 years and older. The third shot should be taken six months or more following the previous shot.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211010054857/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn

Quote: "Authorities are maintaining international entry restrictions and domestic measures consistent with those imposed elsewhere to limit the spread of COVID-19 as of Oct. 4.   International commercial flights remain suspended. The only way to enter or leave the country by air is via a limited number of charter flights allowed to operate at Turkmenabat International Airport (CRZ). All land borders are closed until further notice.    Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and critical infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. Unvaccinated foreign nationals must present proof of a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours and must undergo a 21-day quarantine in a state-run facility. Vaccinated travelers must self-isolate for only seven days and may do so at their place of residence.    Authorities test all international travelers on arrival regardless of vaccination status. While freight transporters are generally allowed entry, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must possess a negative COVID-19 test certificate signed within the previous 24 hours."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20211008193456/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/531206/turkmenistan-authorities-maintaining-nationwide-covid-19-countermeasures-as-of-oct-4-update-18

Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and critical infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. Vaccinated travelers must self-isolate for only seven days and may do so at their place of residence.    Authorities test all international travelers on arrival regardless of vaccination status. While freight transporters are generally allowed entry, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must possess a negative COVID-19 test certificate signed within the previous 24 hours."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20211008193456/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/531206/turkmenistan-authorities-maintaining-nationwide-covid-19-countermeasures-as-of-oct-4-update-18

Starting September 6, entry into establishments such as concerts, cinemas, theaters, and crowded events will require proof of vaccination, or a negative PCR test taken 48 hours prior to the event. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older. including foreign nationals with Turkish residency. Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to enter into these venues or participate in crowded events.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211025072613/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Starting September 6, intercity travel by plane, bus, train, or other public transportation will require proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test taken 48 hours prior to travel. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older. including foreign nationals with Turkish residency. Travel using a private vehicle will not require proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test.  Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to board public transportation. https://web.archive.org/web/20211025072613/https://tr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

All arrivals into Turkey aged 6 and over, including Turkish citizens and residence permit holders, must complete an online form (Form for Entry to Turkey) a maximum of 72 hours prior to travel. You do not need to do this if youâre transiting Turkey on the way to another country.    All arrivals (aged 12 and over) - including those arriving from the UK - into Turkey, from countries other than those mentioned below, must have proof of one of the following:    A full course of COVID-19 vaccinations (completed at least 14 days prior to arrival in Turkey)  recent recovery from COVID-19  a negative PCR test (within 72 hours of arrival)  a rapid antigen test (within 48 hours of arrival).  For children aged 11 and under, no PCR test or vaccination certificate is needed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211019123042/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/entry-requirements

The authorities have softened access to a number of social support programs, such as household utilities subsidies and aid to families with children. The changes include (a) increasing norms (by 50 percent) for energy consumption used to determine the amount of subsidy; (b) stopping the disqualification from the household utilities subsidies program of a person that breaches qualification criteria; (c) automatic re-enrollment into the program for the heating season 2020-2021; (d) extending existing social entitlements for the period of the quarantine without the need to reapply; and (e) making private entrepreneurs eligible for the state support for children younger than 10.    https://web.archive.org/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#V

Quote: "If you show COVID-19 symptoms you will undergo testing at government facilities.    If you test positive for COVID-19 will be placed into Red, Yellow and Green categories. If you have a light form of coronavirus infection (asymptomatic), you will be categorised as Green. If you have medium symptoms (e.g. high temperature), you will be categorised as Yellow, and if you have serious symptoms, you will be categorised as Red.    If you are categorised as Green or Yellow, and if approved by a doctor, then you will be allowed to have treatment at home and will be required to comply with existing sanitary-hygiene rules. In Red cases, you will be admitted to hospital. If you are categorised as Green or Yellow and treatment at home is not possible, you will be hospitalised in a dedicated government facility, and discharged after 10 days if no further symptoms are observed.    If you have been in contact with a person who tests positive for COVID-19, you will no longer be automatically quarantined but are required to self-isolate for 14-days and be subject to medical monitoring."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20211026003600/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uzbekistan/coronavirus
